69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:06): i just meant, the idea of deciding whether a group agrees to something or not being resolved by defining the group as those who agree
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:07): either through gerrymandering or attrition
bdf7d7409da19264fa0c4bf6b4f2d0cc (02:09): speaking of, do you read the public-canvas-api list or know what they are up to?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:26): hober: congrats (saw your tweet)
4e30d3f6785f2b05321da9cd03919811 (02:30): great word, gerrymandering
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:31): bdf7d7409da19264fa0c4bf6b4f2d0cc: i read it, wasn't aware they were up to anything
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:31): bdf7d7409da19264fa0c4bf6b4f2d0cc: anything in particular?
bdf7d7409da19264fa0c4bf6b4f2d0cc (02:32): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: they keep talking about a shadow DOM in canvas and i'm not sure what they mean if it isn't fallback content
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:34): they seem to be discussing what the spec says without realising the spec has said it for several months now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:34): the idea is that the fallback content of a <canvas> is supposed to be focusable even when the <canvas> isn't falling back
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:34): so that you can make the fallback reflect the image
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:35): this lets you get (for free) things like tabbing around controls
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:35): works in conjunction with the drawFocusRing() method to automatically render focus rings on controls on the canvas
d578361712af3cdb58febae0b7781d8d (02:40): f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4: the first rule of ASI-club is there's no insertion if there is no error
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:44): hober: will you be working on things like http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=10694 ?
d578361712af3cdb58febae0b7781d8d (02:44): f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4: what happens? i'm not talking about web inspector, i'm talking about JS
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (02:46): and tries to call function
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (02:46): because sees call operator
d578361712af3cdb58febae0b7781d8d (02:49): f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4: why do you think there's an error requiring semicolon insertion?
d578361712af3cdb58febae0b7781d8d (02:49): f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4: remember the first rule of ASI fight-club
d578361712af3cdb58febae0b7781d8d (02:49): if there's no error, there is no insertion
d578361712af3cdb58febae0b7781d8d (02:49): f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4: you're thinking the \n should cause a ; to be inserted?
d578361712af3cdb58febae0b7781d8d (02:49): v8 and ff4 are correct
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (02:51): yes but many ppl do not insert ; in js code
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (02:51): it's fine to use menu for menus, isn't it?
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (02:54): js should has minimal count of traps for newbies imho
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (02:54): i mean, it says those "actions" can be links... and going to a different page is an immediate action, isn't it?
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (02:56): what's that supposed to mean?
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (02:58): english dictonary fail. sorry
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (02:59): yes, it is
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:00): but if it's integrated into your text editor or IDE, it's not much of an issue
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (03:02): may be is better to fix lang issue instead keep "backward compatibility"?
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:02): you can't really fix js
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:03): it's out there... gotta deal with it
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:03): js is the least of my problems though
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (03:04): js has alot of traps, bugs and fails imho
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:04): it's very straightforward imo
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:05): man there's all kinds of things that aren't specced right for type=email multiple
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:05): i write lots of js and it's generally completely pain-free
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:06): oh it's the 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e :) is it fine to use menu for menus? :f
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:06): what do you mean by "menus"?
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:06): top/side navigation bar thingies
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:06): those things which are typically done with ul elements
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:07): "The menu element represents a list of commands."
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:07): if your "navigation bar" is a list of commands, then sure
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:07): and a command can be a link... and going to some site is some immediate action...
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:08): so... uhm... it's fine, isn't it?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:08): <a href=""></a> is a command, per the html spec, yes

cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:10): thing is, i kinda prefer using menu instead of ul for those things, since i wont have to re-reset them and because i think menu makes a little bit more sense than ul
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:10): from the html spec's point of view, either is defensible
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:10): thank you :x

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:11): <menu> really is intended for drop-down menus (type=toolbar) and context menus (type=context), the list state (no type attribute) is basically only allowed for historical reasons
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:11): <nav> is the important thing to have in your DOM if you have a navigation list
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:11): ye, nav>menu>li>a ish

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:12): whether you do <nav><p><a>...</a><p><a>...</a></nav>, <nav><ul><li><a>...</a><li><a>...</a></ul></nav>, <nav><menu><p><a>...</a><p><a>...</a></menu></nav>, or <nav><menu><li><a>...</a><li><a>....</a></menu></nav> is really up to you

cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (03:15): f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4, the closure compiler also helps you to write somewhat more robust js. there is also the option to skip js entirely (e.g. by using GTW, pyjamas, and things like that)
